columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about convertible calculations.

To start with, let us define conversion value.

The ability of a bond to be converted into common stocks is a feature of a special type of bond. The converted amount into common stock is the **conversion value** of the bond.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem: 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Face value of bond |$1,000 | 
|Current value of bond |$960 | 
|Conversion ratio |1 bond=18 shares | 
|Coupon rate |4.9%    |
|Yield rate |7.4% | 
|Maturity date | 40 periods (20 years semiannually) | 
|Current stock price |$45/share |

## Requirement 1

We are asked to solve the conversion ratio, conversion price, and conversion premium. 

The conversion ratio is 18 shares of stock for each bond,**1 bond=18 shares.**

## Requirement 2

We are asked to solve the straight bond value and the conversion value. 

The **straight bond value** is the equivalent value of the bond it will not be converted into shares of stocks.

The equation to solve the straight bond value is illustrated below:

  

$$\textbf{SBV}=\text{Interest}\times\left[\frac{1-\frac{1}{(1+\text{r}^{\text{n}})}}{\text{r}}\right]\times\left[\frac{\text{FV}}{(1+\text{r}^{\text{n}})}\right]$$

Where: 

- SBV - Straight Bond Value
- r - Yield rate
- n - Number of periods
- FV - Face Value

To start with, let us solve the semi-annual interest payments: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Interest Payments}&=\text{Face Value}\times\left(\frac{\text{Coupon Rate}}{2}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\$1,000\times\left(\frac{0.049}{2}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\$1,000\times0.0245\\[20pt]
&=\$24.50
\end{aligned}$$

The coupon rate is divided by two since interest payments are done semiannually. This rate is multiplied by the face value to determine the interest payments. 

Thus, the semi-annual interest payment is $24.50.

Now, let us solve the yield rate if the payment terms are semiannual. 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{r}&=\frac{0.074}{2}\\[20pt]
&=0.037
\end{aligned}$$

The yield rate of 7.4% is divided by two. 

Hence, the yield rate we are going to use on the straight bond value equation is 0.037 or 3.7%.

Now, using the equation in Step 8, the straight bond value is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{SBV}&={\$24.50}\times\left[\frac{1-\frac{1}{(1+0.037)^{40}}}{0.037}\right]+\left[\frac{\$1,000}{(1+0.037)^{40}}\right]\\[20pt]
&={\$24.50}\times\left[\frac{1-\frac{1}{(1.037)^{40}}}{0.037}\right]+\left[\frac{\$1,000}{(1.037)^{40}}\right]\\[20pt]
&={\$24.50}\times\left[\frac{1-\frac{1}{4.277108}}{0.037}\right]+\left[\frac{\$1,000}{4.277108}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$24.50\times\left[\frac{\left(1-0.2338\right)}{0.037}\right]+\$233.80\\[20pt]
&=\$24.50\times\left(\frac{0.7662}{0.037}\right)+\$233.80\\[20pt]
&=\left(\$24.50\times\$20.71\right)+\$233.80\\[15pt]
&=\$507.40+\$233.80\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$741.20}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the straight bond value is $741.20.

Then, the conversion value is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Conversion Value}&=\text{Conversion Ratio}\times\text{Current Stock Price}\\[15pt]
&=18\space\text{shares}\times\$45/\text{share}\\[15pt]
&=\$810
\end{aligned}$$


The conversion ratio in the number of shares is multiplied by the current stock price to determine the conversion value. 

Therefore, the conversion value is $810.

## Requirement 3

We are asked to compute the stock price for the conversion value and straight bond value to be equal.

## Requirement 4

We are asked to solve the option value of the bond. 

The equal total value of the option is shown below: 

$$\textbf{Option}=(\text{CV of Bond-Conv. Value})+(\text{Conv. Value-SBV})$$

The difference between the current value of the bond and conversion value; conversion value and straight bond value - are added to determine the total value of the option.
